author: Jack Blanchard
title: Brussels chief Donald Tusk vows to make Brexit the 'least painful' possible for the EU
text:

Donald Tusk spoke of his determination to make the Brexit “divorce” as painless as possible for the EU. 
The EU President, who met Japanese premiere Shinzo Abe in Brussels, said the remaining bloc members will hold a special summit on April 29 to agree a negotiating position ahead of the two-year talks on a deal. 
Mr Tusk said: “Our main priority for the negotiations must be to create as much certainty and clarity as possible for all citizens, companies and member states negatively affected by Brexit .” 
Theresa May is preparing to trigger Article 50 next Wednesday and Mr Tusk has vowed to publish a draft response within 48 hours of getting her letter. 
The Scottish Parliament will on Wednesday formally vote for a second independence referendum after Nicola Sturgeon warned it would be “unfair and utterly unsustainable” for Westminster to block the move. Donald Tusk will hold a special summit (Photo: REUTERS) 
Scottish National Party MSPs will join with their Green Party allies in Holyrood to demand another poll after losing the 2014 referendum. 
The final decision must be taken in Westminster however and Theresa May has already ruled out allowing a second vote before Britain leaves the EU in March 2019. 
But speaking at the start of a two-day debate in the Scottish Parliament, Ms Sturgeon said: “It will simply not be acceptable for the UK government to stand as a roadblock to the democratically expressed will of this parliament.” 
The Scottish First Minister had originally demanded a second vote between the autumn of 2018 and spring 2019, supposedly to give Scotland a chance to remain in the EU. 
Yesterday she said she would be flexible about the dates, telling MSPs: “If the UK government disagrees with that timeframe, then they should set out a clear alternative and the rationale for it. 
“I am, within reason, happy to have that discussion to see if we can find common ground.” Read More Millions dealt double blow as high inflation sees living costs increase faster than wages PM says the Brexit notification is 'one of the most important documents in the UK's recent history' (Photo: Getty) 
It comes as Mrs May prepares to trigger Article 50 next Wednesday and start the two-year countdown to Brexit . 
At a Cabinet meeting yesterday the PM told Ministers hailed the “historic event” which she said would see Britain begin a “bold new chapter as a prosperous, open and global nation”. 
Mrs May described the letter she will send to EU President Donald Tusk giving formal notification of Brexit as “one of the most important documents in our country’s recent history”. 
Mr Tusk has already vowed to publish a draft response from the EU within 48 hours of receiving the letter. 
He announced the remaining EU countries will hold a special summit on April 29 to agree their negotiating position ahead of the two-year Brexit talks. 
Speaking in Brussels Mr Tusk said his priority was making sure the “divorce” was the “least painful” possible for the EU. 
“Our main priority for the negotiations must be to create as much certainty and clarity as possible for all citizens, companies and member states negatively affected by Brexit ,” he said. Read More How to beat Brexit when it comes to your holiday: Expert tips to help stretch your pound further Lords warn of damage to aviation and broadcasting industries if negotiations unsuccessful (Photo: Getty) 
Experts fear the two-year timeframe for talks will be too tight for Britain to secure a comprehensive free trade agreement to replace its membership of the single market. 
In a report today, a House of Lords committee says failure to do so would be deeply damaging to Britain’s aviation and broadcasting industries. 
The Lords EU internal market committee said neither industry has World Trade Organisation arrangements to fall back on if Mrs May walks away without a deal. 
The committee warned UK airlines could suddenly lose their right to fly to and from European states - and even to the USA, where flights are governed by the EU-US Open Skies agreement. 
The peers urged the PM to secure a transitional deal so firms can continue to trade in the period between Britain’s EU departure in 2019 and the conclusion of a free trade agreement, which will “almost certainly take more than two years” to negotiate. 
Committee chair Lord Whitty said: “To protect the UK’s status as a global leader of trade in services, the Government will need to secure the most comprehensive trade agreement ever agreed with the EU. 
“Walking away from negotiations without a deal would badly damage UK plc - particularly in sectors such as aviation and broadcasting which have no WTO rules to fall back on.” Like us on Facebook
